conclusion: To find the acceleration of the particle during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph and calculate the slope of the line at those points.
At t = 1 second, the velocity is v = 2 m/s.
At t = 2 seconds, the velocity is v = -2 m/s (negative because the particle is moving in the opposite direction).
At t = 3 seconds, the velocity is v = 0 m/s.

premise: The slope of the line at t = 1 second is given by the change in velocity divided by the change in time. v1 = 2 m/s at t1 = 1 second, v2 = -2 m/s at t2 = 2 seconds.
The slope of the line at t = 2 second is given by the change in velocity divided by the change in time. v2 = -2 m/s at t2 = 2 seconds, v3 = 0 m/s at t3 = 3 seconds.
The slope of the line at t = 1 second is -4 m/s^2, and the slope of the line at t = 2 second is 2 m/s^2.
conclusion: Since the slope of the line at t = 1 second is negative, the acceleration of the particle during this time interval is negative.

premise: The acceleration is the negative of the slope, and the slope is 2 m/s^2.
conclusion: The acceleration during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds is -2 m/s^2.
